dialogue: Look at these two bars. Both have the same amount shaded, but the pieces are different sizes. Which fraction is greater?

workspace.description: Bar divided into sixths with 2 pieces shaded
Bar divided into ninths with 2 pieces shaded

correct_answer.context: 2/6 > 2/9 because sixths are bigger pieces than ninths. Same count shaded, but bigger pieces means greater fraction.

success_path_dialogue: That's right. Same count, but bigger pieces win.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Look at the size of the shaded pieces in each bar. Which pieces are bigger?

Let's think about this together. Both bars have 2 pieces shaded - that's the same. But look carefully at the size of each piece. Sixths are bigger pieces than ninths. When the count is the same, bigger pieces make a greater fraction.

Let me walk you through this comparison. Both fractions have 2 pieces shaded - that part is the same. But here's the key: we need to compare the size of the pieces. Look at the bar showing 2/6 - each sixth is a bigger piece. Now look at the bar showing 2/9 - each ninth is a smaller piece. When we have the same count of pieces, the one with bigger pieces is greater. So 2/6 is greater than 2/9. That's how we compare fractions with the same numerator - bigger pieces win.
